action.action-desc: Mrs. Boxer (for herself and Ms. Collins) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on Armed Services

form.official-title: To establish eligibility, assignment, training, and certification requirements for sexual assault forensic examiners for the Armed Forces, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Military SAFE Standards Act.

section.header: Requirements relating to sexual assault forensic examiners for the Armed Forces

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2), the individuals who may be assigned to duty as a sexual assault forensic examiner (SAFE) for the Armed Forces shall be members of the Armed Forces and civilian personnel of the Department of Defense or Department of Homeland Security who are as follows:

An independent duty corpsman or equivalent may be assigned to duty as a sexual assault forensic examiner for the Armed Forces if the assignment of an individual specified in paragraph (1) is impracticable.
The Secretary concerned shall ensure the availability of an adequate number of sexual assault forensic examiners for the Armed Forces through the following:

subparagraph.text: Assignment of at least one sexual assault forensic examiner at each military medical treatment facility under the jurisdiction of such Secretary, whether in the United States or overseas.

If assignment as described in subparagraph (A) is infeasible or impracticable, entry into agreements with facilities, whether Governmental or otherwise, with appropriate resources for the provision of sexual assault forensic examinations, for the provision of sexual assault forensic examinations for the Armed Forces.

paragraph.text: The Secretary concerned shall ensure the availability of an adequate number of sexual assault forensic examiners for naval vessels through the assignment of at least one sexual assault forensic examiner for each naval vessel.

The Secretary concerned shall establish and maintain, and update when appropriate, a training and certification program for sexual assault forensic examiners under the jurisdiction of such Secretary. The training and certification programs shall apply uniformly to all sexual assault forensic examiners under the jurisdiction of the Secretaries.
Each training and certification program under this subsection shall include the following:

subparagraph.text: Training in sexual assault forensic examinations by qualified personnel who possess—

clause.text: a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner—adolescent/adult (SANE–A) certification or equivalent certification; or
training and clinical or forensic experience in sexual assault forensic examinations similar to that required for a certification described in clause (i).

subparagraph.text: A minimum of 40 hours of coursework for participants in sexual assault forensic examinations of adults and adolescents.
Ongoing examinations and evaluations on sexual assault forensic examinations.

paragraph.text: The training provided under each training and certification program under this subsection shall incorporate and reflect current best practices and standards on sexual assault forensic examinations.

An individual may not be assigned to duty as a sexual assault forensic examiner for the Armed Forces after the date that is one year after the date of the enactment of this Act unless the individual has completed all training required under the training and certification program under this subsection at the time of assignment.

It is the sense of Congress that each participant who successfully completes all training required under the certification and training program under this subsection should obtain a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner—adolescent/adult certification or equivalent certification by not later than five years after completion of such training.

Any individual providing sexual assault forensic examinations for the Armed Forces under an agreement under subsection (b)(1)(B) shall possess training and experience equivalent to the training and experience required under the training and certification program under this subsection.

subsection.text: In this section, the term Secretary concerned means—

paragraph.text: the Secretary of Defense with respect to matters concerning the Department of Defense; and
the Secretary of Homeland Security with respect to matters concerning the Coast Guard when it is not operating as a service in the Navy.

subsection.text: Section 1725 of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2014 (Public Law 113–66; 127 Stat. 971) is amended by striking subsection (b) (10 U.S.C. 1561 note).
